**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Brockton District Court.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper under **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 231, § 1**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the Brockton District Court.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, § 1**, as the Defendant resides or has its usual place of business in Plymouth County and the events giving rise to this action occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts.

**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.raw_text: **Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901 (1987)**
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Defendant owed a legal duty of care to Plaintiff’s minor child to supervise him with reasonable attention and to protect him from foreseeable harm while he was in Defendant’s custody.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses a proprietor’s general duty to patrons based on foreseeable harm, but it does not address any special duty to supervise or protect a *minor child in the defendant’s custody*. The court frames the duty in terms of ordinary premises liability and foreseeability of an out‑of‑control vehicle, not a custodial or supervisory duty toward children. Thus it provides some general foreseeability language but does not establish the specific duty proposition claimed.
**Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugu.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is ‘foreseeable harm.’… The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

**Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass..proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the Defendant owed a legal duty of care to Plaintiff’s minor child to supervise him with reasonable attention and to protect him from foreseeable harm while he was in Defendant’s custody.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass..support_reasoning: The provided text is a dissent focused entirely on proximate causation, not on whether a duty of care existed or its scope. While Mullins as a majority opinion does recognize a college’s duty to protect its resident students from foreseeable criminal acts, this excerpt neither discusses minors, custody, nor a specific duty to supervise and protect a minor child. Because the quoted portion does not address the duty question at all, it does not support the proposition for which it is cited.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass..relevant_excerpt: In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.

**Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271 (198.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a party assumes a duty of reasonable care when it undertakes to supervise children.
**Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes a landowner’s general duty of reasonable care to lawful entrants on its premises, here a town operating a parking lot. It does not involve or discuss supervision of children, nor any undertaking to supervise as the source of a duty. The case is therefore about premises liability and municipal liability under the Tort Claims Act, not about assumed duties arising from supervision of children.
**Doherty v. Belmont, 396 Mass. 271 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The town’s reliance on these ‘public duty’ cases is misplaced, because the town’s duty in the case at bar does not arise from the general language of a regulatory or criminal statute, but rather from the town’s status as a landowner… A landowner owes a single duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on his premises. Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)… The town owed Doherty a duty of reasonable care in her individual capacity as a parking lot patron…”

**Driscoll v. Worcester, 215 Mass. 493 (.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a party assumes a duty of reasonable care when it undertakes to supervise children.
**Driscoll v. Worcester, 215 Mass. 493 (.case_name: Boston Railroad Holding Co. v. Commonwealth
**Driscoll v. Worcester, 215 Mass. 493 (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the methodology for assessing a Massachusetts corporate franchise tax and the treatment of certain property (cash in bank, merchandise, securities) within that tax framework. It does not discuss tort duties, supervision of children, or any assumption of a duty of reasonable care. Accordingly, it provides no support for the proposition about undertaking to supervise children creating a duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
**Driscoll v. Worcester, 215 Mass. 493 (.relevant_excerpt: This is a petition under St. 1909, c. 490, Part III, § 70, and acts in amendment thereof, for the abatement of a portion of a franchise tax assessed upon the petitioner for the year 1912 and paid by it in October of that year... What is to be taxed is the corporate franchise. In order to tax it, its value must first be determined. The statute accordingly provides a method for arriving at that...

**Brum v. Town of Dartmouth, 428 Mass. 6.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a party assumes a duty of reasonable care when it undertakes to supervise children.
**Brum v. Town of Dartmouth, 428 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on governmental immunity under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act, public duty doctrine, proximate cause, and constitutional claims under § 1983. It does not discuss, recognize, or analyze any general Massachusetts common‑law principle that an actor who undertakes to supervise children thereby assumes a duty of reasonable care. Supervision of children is mentioned only factually in the school setting, not as a doctrinal basis for imposing a duty of care, so this case does not support the proposition cited.
**Brum v. Town of Dartmouth, 428 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: In Brum vs. Dartmouth, the plaintiff… brought suit against the town of Dartmouth and several town and school officials under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act… alleging that the defendants’ negligent failure to maintain adequate security measures at the school and specific failure to protect her son in the presence of a known threat resulted in Robinson’s death… The plaintiff in Brum… also argues that her case falls within the “state-created danger” exception… The defendants in the instant case did not create the danger that resulted in Robinson’s death. They neither created the three assailants’ murderous intent nor invited them onto school property.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable and negligent under the circumstances as defined by **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, and fell below that level of care an ordinarily prudent entity would have exercised under like conditions. See **Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (1991)**.

**Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was unreasonable and negligent under the circumstances as defined by **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, and fell below that level of care an ordinarily prudent entity would have exercised under like conditions. See **Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401 (1991)**.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401.support_reasoning: Ulwick v. DeChristopher does not hold that the defendant’s conduct was negligent under G.L. c. 231, § 85 or that it fell below the standard of care of an ordinarily prudent person. Instead, the SJC affirms summary judgment for the defendant, expressly concluding that no common-law duty existed under the circumstances and rejecting statutory violations as a basis for civil liability. The case is thus authority against, not for, a finding of negligence on similar facts.
**Ulwick v. DeChristopher, 411 Mass. 401.relevant_excerpt:
“Since no common law duty exists here, it follows that the statutes relied on by the plaintiff do not of themselves create a cause of action in tort.” (411 Mass. at 408)

“We think the factor of control should continue to be the dominant consideration in a case of this type… In the absence of such control in this case, we are not prepared to say that the common law should provide a remedy on the negligent encouragement theory advanced by the plaintiff.” (411 Mass. at 406-407)

**Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain proper supervision was the legal and proximate cause of J.C.’s injuries.
**Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739.support_reasoning: The opinion does not support the proposition that defendant’s failure to maintain proper supervision was the legal and proximate cause of J.C.’s injuries. Instead, the Supreme Judicial Court holds that Westwood owed no duty to provide safe passage across the state highway, that its only voluntarily assumed duty (hiring police for traffic control) was performed with due care, and that the jury’s verdict in favor of the city shows the officer was not negligent. Thus, the court rejects, rather than affirms, any theory that Westwood’s supervision or lack thereof legally and proximately caused the injuries.
**Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, Westwood voluntarily undertook one specific task, that of hiring police officers to direct pedestrians across Route 1A between the south parking lot and the track. Thus, Westwood was cast with a duty to exercise due care in carrying out the particular task of hiring those officers. … [T]he jury verdict that the city of Revere was not negligent supports the conclusion that Westwood performed this duty with due care… Hence, even if we were to assume that Officer Falzarano was Westwood’s agent, there is no ground for attributing to Westwood vicarious liability for his acts.”

**Keenan v. Eli Lilly & Co., 418 Mass. 6.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently recognize the right of a parent to recover for medical expenses incurred on behalf of a minor injured child under general negligence principles.
**Keenan v. Eli Lilly & Co., 418 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not Keenan v. Eli Lilly & Co. and does not address tort damages, parents’ rights, minors’ claims, or recovery of medical expenses for injured children. It is an attorney discipline case concerning suspension after a federal felony conviction. Because the decision does not speak to the asserted negligence principle at all, it cannot support the claimed proposition.
**Keenan v. Eli Lilly & Co., 418 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt on parental recovery of a child’s medical expenses appears in this opinion; it concerns attorney discipline for conviction of conspiracy to defraud the United States.]

**Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u201.raw_text: **Ferriter v. Daniel O’Connell’s Sons, Inc., 381 Mass. 507 (1980)**
**Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u201.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently recognize the right of a parent to recover for medical expenses incurred on behalf of a minor injured child under general negligence principles.
**Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u201.case_name: Ferriter v. Daniel O'Connell's Sons, Inc.
**Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u201.support_reasoning: Ferriter does not break new ground on the point, but it expressly recites and relies on the established Massachusetts common-law rule that a parent may recover, in a separate action, for medical and care expenses reasonably incurred for an injured minor child. The court cites and discusses Dennis v. Clark and related cases in describing this traditional parental cause of action in negligence, and later reaffirms King v. Viscoloid that such parental claims are independent of the employee‑child’s own claim. This squarely aligns with the proposition that Massachusetts courts consistently recognize a parent’s right to recover such expenses under general negligence principles.
**Ferriter v. Daniel O\u2019Connell\u201.relevant_excerpt:
Moreover, the parent could recover for labor performed and expenses reasonably incurred in the child's care. Dennis v. Clark, 2 Cush. 347 (1848). As in actions for abduction and seduction, the requirement of actual loss of services withered, becoming a mere fiction. Id. See W. Prosser, supra, § 125 at 890.
...
In King, a mother sued her son's employer for loss of the son's services and for expenses incurred in nursing and caring for him. The workmen's compensation insurer had made various payments to the son. This court upheld the mother's claim.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6A & 85**.proposition: Defendant’s failures breached a duty recognized under Massachusetts common law and supported by **G.L. c. 231, §§ 6A & 85**, which require full compensation for harm caused by negligent acts.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B**.proposition: Award compensatory damages in an amount to be determined at trial, but reasonably estimated at not less than **$3,500**, plus interest and costs pursuant to **G.L. c. 231, § 6B**;
